trial_identification.studytitle: A Pilot Study of Topical Honey for the Treatment of Nappy Rash
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In children less than 5 yrs old with nappy rash is topical medical-grade honey acceptable and does it appear to reduce the severity of nappy rash?

interventions.interventions: Topical medical grade honey applied to nappy rash in a thin film sufficient to cover the affected area, at each nappy change for 2 weeks.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Nappy rash severity assessed by a 5 point nappy rash severity score.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at final visit after 2 weeks

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Subjective assessment of nappy rash severity, measured by visual analogue score (VAS)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at final visit after 2 weeks

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Objective assessment of global nappy rash severity, measured by VAS
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at final visit after 2 weeks

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Acceptability of honey therapy, measured by VAS

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Aged <5 at the time of enrolment Doctors diagnosis of nappy rash
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Requirement for topical or systemic corticosteroids, as judged by treating doctor Requirement for antibiotic therapy, as judged by treating doctor Known or suspected allergy to honey or dressings Any other condition which, at the investigators discretion, it is believed may present a safety risk or impact the feasibility of the study or the study results

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
There are reasons to believe that medical grade-honey applied directly to skin may be an effective treatment for nappy rash. In this study parents/guardians of 10 children with nappy rash will apply medical grade honey to the napkin area at each nappy change.
After two weeks the nappy rash will be assessed to look at changes in severity. Participants will also be asked about their experience of using honey.
This trial will provide useful information on the practicalities of topical honey as a treatment for nappy rash. It will also give an initial signal as to whether honey may be effective.
